title: 111_hr3452
content: The Act is titled the "Recoupment of Wall Street Bonus Act" and pertains to bonuses received from certain TARP recipients. The "Recoupment of Wall Street Bonus Act" applies to employees or former employees of covered TARP recipients, ensuring that their tax liability is not reduced by TARP bonuses received, with the tax being the sum of the tax on the reduced income by the bonus and 100% of the bonus amount. The "Recoupment of Wall Street Bonus Act" applies to employees of covered TARP recipients, ensuring that their tax liability is not reduced by TARP bonuses received. A disqualified bonus payment refers to any additional retention, incentive, or bonus payment beyond regular service compensation, excluding commissions, welfare benefits, and expense reimbursements. Any reimbursement by a covered TARP recipient of the tax imposed under subsection (a) shall be treated as a disqualified bonus payment to the taxpayer liable for such tax. The term "covered TARP recipient" includes persons receiving capital infusions exceeding $5,000,000,000 under the Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008, Federal National Mortgage Association, Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, affiliated group members, and partnerships with over 50% ownership. The term "covered TARP recipient" includes partnerships with over 50% ownership by individuals described in subparagraphs (A), (B), or (C), and an exception for TARP recipients who repay assistance exceeding $5,000,000,000. Terms in this section have the same meaning as in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The section discusses the coordination with the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, regulations to be prescribed by the Secretary of the Treasury, and the effective date for disqualified bonus payments received after December 31, 2008. All tax revenue from section 1 will be deposited at the Department of Housing and Urban Development for funding programs under section 4.
